evidence.snippet: With all the theories and words written about the speed of <mark>light</mark> the question why is the recorded speed of <mark>light</mark> what it is what effect <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.1270044144)">causes</mark> it to be what it is why is it held back at the maximum speed of 186,000 mps is space filled with a substance we have <mark>not</mark> discovered yet a substance that retards anything that goes faster than 186,000 mps for instance dark matter which is accompanied by dark energy THE SPEED OF <mark>LIGHT</mark> NEEDS MUCH MORE INVESTIGATION IN MANY MORE WAYS !! @Ashik Shalin: Protons and neutrons do have constituent particles (they re called quarks), but electrons do <mark>not.</mark> It is true that the term speed of <mark>light</mark> is a way to say <mark>light</mark> moves at 186,000 mpsec same as I might say my car will do a mile a min <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.41013902352000003)">however</mark> I can tell you why it will do the speed of a mile a min <mark>light</mark> is just one of many <mark>things</mark> that move at 186,000 mpsec all electrical <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.0368818088)">functions</mark> move at that speed etc THE <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.30652482536000003)">FACTS</mark> ARE THAT <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.03851224128)">NO ONE</mark> HAS ANY IDEA WHY THIS SPEED LIMIT EXISTS !ONE <mark>THING</mark> FOR <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.0215921553)">SURE</mark> THERE IS A REASON ! IT HAS <mark>NOT</mark> BEEN DESCOVERED YET but it will be !!in 10yrs 100yrs 1000yrs 10,000yrs but it will be discovered !!!

askscience Why is <mark>light</mark> the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in the universe? After reading RobotRollCall's explanation of why we can never travel faster than <mark>light,</mark> this question popped into my head: What properties of <mark>light</mark> ensure that it is the absolute <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> that will ever exist in the universe? How do we know that there <mark>isn't</mark> some undiscovered substance (dark matter? something similar?) that <mark>isn't</mark> travelling through the universe faster than <mark>light</mark> can?

Since you already know that <mark>light</mark> is the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> around, we'll look at what other speedy items our universe, and maybe even a <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.2400031356)">fictional</mark> universe or two, has to <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.3661650972)">offer</mark> -- from animals to superheroes and planets to toilets. Because, yes, it stands to reason that if toilets can move, then there must be one that moves <mark>fastest.</mark> And <mark>don't</mark> tell me you're <mark>not</mark> curious to know which one holds that honor. So leash your cheetah, tell Usain Bolt to <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.0399060888)">take</mark> a knee and buckle your seat belt as we power through our list of <mark>fastest</mark> things.

<mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.035423682)">Ultimately,</mark> the work may contribute to the development of faster computers that carry <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.3116533852)">information</mark> in <mark>light</mark> particles. <mark>Not</mark> everyone is convinced the NEC scientists did what they <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.373749712)">claim.</mark> Aephraim Steinberg, a physicist at the University of Toronto, said the <mark>light</mark> particles coming out of the cesium chamber <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.030987179440000002)">may not</mark> have been the same ones that entered, so he questions whether the speed of <mark>light</mark> was broken. Still, the work is important, he said: The interesting <mark>thing</mark> is how did they manage to produce <mark>light</mark> that looks exactly like something that didn t get there yet?

No? Now let't find out some of the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in the world together. <mark>Fastest</mark> <mark>Thing</mark> in the Universe The <mark>Fastest</mark> Man The list of <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in the universe <mark>wouldn't</mark> be complete without mentioning the <mark>fastest</mark> man ever recorded to date.

But in reality the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in this Universe, which we can never beat is our imagination. Our imagination has <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.38541531)">no</mark> bounds and can travel trillions and trillions of <mark>light</mark> years in just one second even without our knowledge. Yes, knowledge has the power travel much faster than a <mark>light</mark> travelling in this universe. We can imagine stars that are millions and millions of <mark>light</mark> years away in just one second and you can think about it in just seconds, whereas many <mark>light</mark> years are required to travel that distance and know about that star or to <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.2668381738)">learn</mark> more about that stars.

In modern physics, <mark>light</mark> is regarded as the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in the universe, and its velocity in empty space as a fundamental constant of nature. The speed of <mark>light</mark> in a vacuum is presently defined to be exactly 299,792,458 m/s (about 186,282.397 miles per second). That s basically the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> the human species has ever experienced today. If you travel around the earth s equator at the speed of <mark>light</mark> you will travel around the entire planet earth 7.4 times in approximately one second.

unpopularopinion The speed of <mark>light</mark> is only the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> we currently know about. Speed of <mark>light</mark> is said to be basically the speed limit of the universe. I call lies. It s the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> we know about or can observe.

<mark>Light</mark> <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.030987179440000002)">Might Not</mark> Be the <mark>Fastest</mark> <mark>Thing</mark> in the Universe Italian physicists say they've recorded sub-atomic particles that travel faster than the speed of <mark>light.</mark> If true, it would disprove Einstein's theory of special relativity. Meanwhile, in America, we've managed to perfect the technology to <mark style="background-color: rgba(0,255,0,0.0549631348)">measure</mark> the speed of pizza.

Did you know that <mark>light</mark> is <mark>not</mark> the <mark>fastest</mark> <mark>thing</mark> in the universe? aqPdPVUL wcUYabOIBFRya kfercrxNadmMlsjPUABBgdLnoxk Answer Wiki Yes, it's all about perception. As speed is a relative concept with <mark style="background-color: rgba(255,0,0,0.38541531)">no</mark> absolute.
